items.content_html: Tens of thousands of people from all over Serbia gathered on Saturday in the northern town of Novi Sad to commemorate the victims of a railway station disaster a year ago. The rally was also a massive display of boiling discontent with the government of autocratic President Aleksandar Vucic. The collapse of a concrete canopy at the Novi Sad train station last Nov. 1 killed 16 people. The tragedy triggered youth-led street protests and a nationwide movement demanding political changes that have seriously shaken Vucic's tight hold on power.

items.content_html:

Ameen al-Zein, like many in Gaza, was overjoyed by the news of the ceasefire. It was a rare moment of relief after years of fear and loss. On Tuesday night he gave an interview to a local NGO urging people to return to their homes in northern Gaza now that fighting had stopped. Just half an hour later, Zein was dead, killed in an Israeli bombing on the school where he had been sheltering in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza.

He died without being able to fulfil his vow to his wife that they would return to Beit Lahia and pitch a tent over the rubble, eager to be home even if their house was no longer there.

items.title: Weather tracker: Hurricane Melissa leaves trail of destruction across Caribbean
items.content_html:
Category 5 storm is most powerful to strike Jamaica and has caused death and destruction in Cuba and Haiti

Hurricane Melissa has wreaked havoc across parts of the Caribbean in recent days, after first making landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday night as a category 5 storm ‚Äì the highest strength. This was the most powerful storm to strike the island nation, packing winds of up to 185mph at its peak.

Western parts of Jamaica were worst hit, with 90% of homes in the town of Black River losing their roof or being destroyed entirely. Roughly three-quarters of the country lost electricity, with at least 19 people known to have lost their lives at the time of publication. The cleanup operation was hampered by thunderstorms even after Melissa cleared to the north. The hurricane continued northwards, but was a slightly weakened category 3 storm by the time it made landfall in Cuba. Nonetheless, the storm continued to bring winds of up to 120mph and torrential rains.

items.title: Rescuing Lake Prespa through cross-border activism
items.content_html: Cross-border cooperation is a rare phenomenon in the Balkans. NGOs in Greece, Albania and North Macedonia are swimming against the tide and working together to protect a lake that has shores in all three countries.

items.title: Germany: 500,000 birds culled as flu spreads
items.content_html: Dozens of cases of bird flu have been reported across the country, especially in north-eastern regions. The virus isn't particularly dangerous for humans, but could result in higher prices for poultry and eggs.

items.content_html: Around 100 trips have been affected, including on the main line between Paris and Marseille. Repair work is set to last until early evening, with full operations not expected to be restored until Tuesday morning.

items.content_html: Long-distance train travel often costs more and takes longer than a flight, but for some people, it's the only way to go. Meet Mark Smith, the man from Seat 61.

items.title: Football: Afghan women make statement on international stage
items.content_html: Afghanistan's female footballers have been fighting in exile to get back to playing internationally for years. On Sunday, their moment arrived, but their mission is far from complete.

items.title: Germany news: Munich votes in favor of Olympics bid
items.content_html: Residents in the city of Munich have voted in favor of bidding to host the Olympics in 2036, 2040 or 2044. Meanwhile, Germany's police union has called for tighter security at train stations. DW has more.

items.title: Romania opens world's largest Orthodox church
items.content_html: The construction of the largest Orthodox Christian church in the world took 15 years, with thousands flocking to the opening. It has an interior capacity for up to 5,000 worshippers.

items.title: UK police arrest wrongly released migrant sex offender

items.title: Kurdish rebel group PKK says withdrawing forces from Turkey

items.title: Alone at sea, unaccompanied refugee minors in mortal danger

items.title: France: Suspects arrested over Louvre heist
items.content_html: People suspected of involvement in the theft of valuable jewels from Paris' Louvre museum have been arrested, the Paris prosecutor says.

items.title: Troops, aid, influence? Turkey's role in Gaza
items.content_html: Israel doesn't like it, but US President Donald Trump has brought Turkey into Gaza ceasefire planning anyway. What role can the country play, and what advantages can it expect from getting involved?

items.title: Is Germany's far-right populist AfD party spying for Russia?
items.content_html: Lawmakers accuse the Alternative for Germany (AfD) party of using its parliamentary powers to gather intelligence on Germany's critical infrastructure to share it with Russia.

items.title: Germany to ramp up aerial surveillance of Russian submarines

items.title: Can the West break China's grip on rare earths?

items.content_html: Be it sci-fi, immigration or even artificial intelligence, the concept of aliens mirrors how we define fear, fascination and the "others" among us.

items.content_html: German Foreign Minister Johann Wadephul has postponed his planned visit to China after Beijing confirmed only one substantive meeting.

items.title: What is methane and what's its role in climate change?
items.content_html: Methane is short-lived but its planet-heating effects are much stronger than CO2. A new report says action on cutting the gas is too slow. Where does it come from, and what can we do to stop it polluting the atmosphere?

items.title: Thailand to let Myanmar refugees work to counter aid cuts and labour shortages
items.content_html:

Thailand is setting a regional precedent this month by giving refugees permission to work in the country in an effort to tackle aid cuts and its own labour shortages.

More than 87,000 refugees living in nine refugee camps along Thailand‚Äôs border with Myanmar have been totally reliant on handouts of food and foreign aid.

items.title: Cruciate ligament rupture: What you need to know

items.title: Delhi awakes to a toxic haze after Diwali as pollution season begins

Myanmar‚Äôs military has raided a major online scam operation near the border with Thailand, detaining more than 2,000 people and seizing dozens of Starlink satellite internet terminals, state media has reported.

items.title: Gen Z pushes back against fast furniture

items.title: Germany meet expectation with win over Luxembourg
